1.rationale:
Looking at the board after our last move, our snake’s head is now at (7,8). We have five apples remaining at (5,1), (1,9), (5,0), (5,5), and (1,8). Let’s consider our safe moves from (7,8):

• UP would take us to (7,9), but the board shows a “T” there—a segment of an enemy snake. That move would be unsafe.
• RIGHT takes us to (8,8), which is safe but doesn’t bring us closer to our target apple.
• LEFT brings us to (6,8), a good option since it moves us toward the x-coordinate of the apple.
• DOWN takes us to (7,7); this also moves us closer vertically (toward the apple at y = 5).

Between LEFT and DOWN, both seem safe. However, note that our target apple (5,5) lies diagonally down‐and‐to‑the‑left. If we move DOWN, we’re moving closer in the y–direction (from 8 to 7) and still only two steps away horizontally (7 to 5). In subsequent turns we could continue with LEFT moves to complete the approach. 

Thus, to steadily approach the apple at (5,5) while keeping a safe distance from enemy segments, I decide that my next move should be DOWN.

Next move: DOWN.

1.rationale:
Our current board shows our snake head at (7,6) and our target apple at (5,5). To compare our options:

• If we move UP → we’d go to (7,7), but that square is occupied by an enemy segment (“T”) so that’s dangerous.
• If we move RIGHT → we’d end up at (8,6), which is safe but doesn’t bring us any closer to the target.
• If we move LEFT → we’d go to (6,6). From (6,6), our distance to the apple becomes |6–5| + |6–5| = 1 + 1 = 2.
• If we move DOWN → we’d land at (7,5). From there, our distance to the apple is |7–5| + |5–5| = 2 + 0 = 2.

Both LEFT and DOWN are safe and both reduce the Manhattan distance to our apple equally. However, moving LEFT brings us one step closer horizontally (moving from x = 7 closer to x = 5) while keeping the vertical gap only 1 unit (y = 6 vs 5). This path can then be followed by a downward move to align perfectly with the apple’s y‑coordinate.

Therefore, the chosen next move is: LEFT.
